name: NPR
text: More than two months after Vanessa Guillen was last seen, her remains were identified by Army investigators. https://t.co/9eGMuFqyu5

name: NPR
text:
Working moms now spend 15 more hours than working dads on childcare and housework, a recent survey finds. But fewer work hours is just one way the pandemic could widen the gender wage gap. 

It's also pulling women out of work altogether. https://t.co/sPYOKZWTyU

name: NPR
text:
The highways and roads that shape our cities were often intentionally built at the expense of Black, Latino and other minority Americans.

Here's how that still hurts communities of color today. ⬇️
https://t.co/H6WcKx4Alk

name: NPR
text: The University System of Georgia is holding in-person classes this fall, with no masks required. It's an anomaly among top public universities — and it will put people at risk, professors say. https://t.co/cMy5MQ4yQs

name: NPR
text: At 79, 74 and 87 years old, respectively, these three veteran songwriters prove that it's possible to release poignant and powerful work late in an artist's career. https://t.co/XHhnfOACvv

name: NPR
text:
A new ordinance in Somerville, Mass., is believed to be the first in the country that officially recognizes multiple-partner relationships in a municipality. @wgbhnews 
https://t.co/8rzPlz3yuU

name: NPR
text:
After a two-month delay due to the coronavirus, HAIM is finally shraing their third record, Women in Music Pt. III — or WIMPIII. 

NPR spoke to the sisters about some of the darker challenges they explore on it. https://t.co/XUXsWITB83

name: NPR
text:
Review: Horror may not be readers' first choice in times like this, but Emma J. Gibbons' new collection of short stories — influenced by both punk rock and classic literature — is full of great characters and genuine scares.
https://t.co/ee4QkTWxHG

name: NPR
text: On this week's episode of https://t.co/T82m3wDccs, we look at why Afro-Latinx folks often get left out of national discussions about Blackness and, in particular, the Black Lives Matter movement. https://t.co/DrvR0CEF86

name: NPR
text:
Just under 100 years ago, well under 1% of NFL players were African American. That figure now stands at approximately 70%. 

The path to that growth begins, in part, with Fritz Pollard. @OnlyAGameNPR 
https://t.co/mqlkGMqXOa
